a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat and binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial = (\<lambda> n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binomial 1001 2 = 500500"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{1001}{2}$. The final Answer is 500500
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{1001}{2} &= \dfrac{1001!}{999!2!} \\ &= \dfrac{1001\times 1000}{2\times 1} \\ &= 1001 \times \dfrac{1000}{2} \\ &= 1001 \times 500 \\ &= \boxed{500500}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat and binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial = (\<lambda> n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binomial 1001 2 = 500500"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the binomial coefficient of the combination of 2 elements from a set of 1001 elements. The final answer is 500,500.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 1001"
and h1 : "k = 2"
shows  "binomial n k = 500500"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{1001}{2}$. The final Answer is 500500
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{1001}{2} &= \dfrac{1001!}{999!2!} \\ &= \dfrac{1001\times 1000}{2\times 1} \\ &= 1001 \times \dfrac{1000}{2} \\ &= 1001 \times 500 \\ &= \boxed{500500}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 1001"
and h1 : "k = 2"
shows  "binomial n k = 500500"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Calculate the binomial coefficient of $n = 1001$ and $k = 2$. The final answer is 500,500.

shows  "binomial n 2 = 500500"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k binom :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binom = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binom 1001 2 = 500500"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{1001}{2}$. The final Answer is 500500
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{1001}{2} &= \dfrac{1001!}{999!2!} \\ &= \dfrac{1001\times 1000}{2\times 1} \\ &= 1001 \times \dfrac{1000}{2} \\ &= 1001 \times 500 \\ &= \boxed{500500}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n k binom :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binom = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binom 1001 2 = 500500"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the binomial coefficient "Choose 1001 items taken 2 at a time," which is denoted as $\binom{1001}{2}$. The final answer is 500,500.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. n choose k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "1001 choose 2 = 500500"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{1001}{2}$. The final Answer is 500500
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{1001}{2} &= \dfrac{1001!}{999!2!} \\ &= \dfrac{1001\times 1000}{2\times 1} \\ &= 1001 \times \dfrac{1000}{2} \\ &= 1001 \times 500 \\ &= \boxed{500500}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. n choose k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "1001 choose 2 = 500500"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the value of the binomial coefficient $\binom{1001}{2}$? The final answer is 500,500.

fixes n k :: nat
